thread.title: Kids can open savings accounts with offers from BankWest, First Option
thread.title_full: Kids can open savings accounts with offers from BankWest, First Option

author: Sophie Elsworth MoneysaverHQ deputy editor
title: Kids can open savings accounts with offers from BankWest, First Option
text:
CASH-conscious junior savers can reap far better returns on their savings than their peers but they need to stick to a plan.
While many interest rates on adult savings accounts are hovering around the two per cent mark — kids’ accounts can reap returns of more than five per cent.
Teaching your kids, or grandchildren, some simple money lessons including the benefits of compound interest on stashed cash can put them well on their way to a healthy financial future.
Data from financial comparison site Canstar shows that keeping to a diligent savings plan can help young people’s savings bloom.
But they need to keep a close eye on their returns to make sure their interest rates don’t plummet as the returns on cash vary widely — from zero per cent up to 5.24 per cent.
The site’s spokesman Mitchell Watson says it’s critical parents guide their children on how to save and keep a check on the terms and conditions of junior savings accounts to ensure they are getting the best deal possible.
Keep a close eye on kids bank account returns to make sure their interest rates don’t plummet. Source: Supplied
“Base rates can vary from little better than nothing to 5.25 per cent if you stick to the account conditions such as minimum monthly deposits and no or low withdrawals,’’ he says.
“If you’re not sure you can do that, you might be better off with an account that has a good flat rate.”
The deals on offer for young savers can quickly change and if you don’t do regular check-ups on the rates on offer, before you know it your youngster might be receiving little or no interest at all.
BankWest’s Kid’s Bonus Saver has the most competitive junior account — for a young customer who pockets a maximum of $250 per month and makes no withdrawals they’ll receive a rate of 5.24 per cent.
First Option Credit Union’s kids bonus saver account is the next best available — offering an interest rate of 5.15 per cent if the child deposits a minimum of $5 per month and makes no withdrawals.
Given the Reserve Bank of Australia has kept the cash rate at a record-low two per cent, for those kids who are receiving interest rates north of five per cent it’s not a bad deal.
